A6.text: The arm and hand motor area is the largest, and occupies the part of precentral gyrus between the leg and face area.

A7.text: These areas are not proportional to their size in the body with the lips, face parts, and hands represented by particularly large areas due to the comparative enrichment and density of motor receptor in these regions.

A8.text: The neural machinery underlying hand movements is a major contributing factor; primates have evolved direct connections between neurons in cortical motor areas and spinal motoneurons, giving the cerebral cortex monosynaptic control over the motoneurons of the hand muscles; placing the hands 'closer' to the brain.
